entry.title: Combined summary - ThunderNetwork - A Java LightningNetwork Implementation Working Today
entry.summary: A Lightning Network Payment-Hub + Client implementation in Java has been developed by a developer named Mats Jerratsch. However, Joseph Poon, a co-author of the Lightning Network white paper, suggests calling it "payment channel networks" instead of a Lightning Network implementation due to differences in design and trust models. Joseph also notes potential issues with the implementation, including exit scamming and malleability risks. The conversation between them revolves around security issues with the implementation and how to mitigate them. Mats Jerratsch and Joseph Poon discuss revocation being the only primary attack vector left with Funding and HTLCs partially mitigated by a reserve.They mention that if Alice were to broadcast a mutated version of Commitment 20, Bob would be out 1 BTC, creating a hostage negotiation situation. However, mitigation can be done by setting the minimum stealable amount of Alice higher than any sum of concurrent payments minus the blockchain fees, allowing Bob to claim all payments and stay in a positive net balance.In other discussions, they explore hypothetical scenarios where one party holds all the funds at one point and the other party holds all the funds at a later point, as well as the potential for a client in the asymmetric model to hold up funds from the server by mutating their transaction.Rusty Russell, another developer, has acknowledged the need for a bitcoinj implementation of Lightning and appreciates any implementation as it is a positive step for the Bitcoin ecosystem.The individual being referred to in the context seems to have achieved great results in a particular area, although it is not specified what those results are related to. However, it is mentioned that he acknowledges the difficulty of following protocols.It can be inferred from the given information that the person's success might have been accompanied by strict adherence to certain protocols or guidelines. Despite this, the individual has recognized the challenges posed by such protocols and the effort required to follow them.Overall, while the specific details of the situation remain unclear, the context suggests that success may be achievable through hard work and discipline, even if it means adhering to challenging protocols.
